titleStmt.title: Variants of Raising of a in pre-tonic (unstressed) closed syllable before ā - CaCCāC
titleStmt.author: Veronika Engler

sourceDesc.p: This is the feature-file for Raising of a in pre-tonic (unstressed) closed syllable before ā - CaCCāC.

revisionDesc.change: updating references to Zotero IDs via update-bibl-refs.xsl

item.label: a > i fillāḥ - ḥimmām
item.desc: also includes raising to u in different environments

item.label: a > a and i become schwa for the Maghreb

wib:featureValueObservation.note: Elderly (70+), Old (60-70) and some middle age speakers show consistent raising of short medial a in unstressed closed syllable before ā, in the pattern CaCCāC(v), as in: nižžār (carpenter), fillāḥ (peasant) and, surprisingly, ḥimmām (toilet, bathroom) and xirbāna (spoiled, broken). Other examples of this, outside of the aforementioned pattern is miʕnāt-a (hence, lit. her meaning). The examples suggest that a preceding /ḥ/ or /x/ does not always block the raising in this pattern.

Young speakers and some middle-aged speakers do not show raising to i of short medial a in unstressed closed syllable before a, unlike Elderly (70+), Old (60-70) and some middle age speakers. Here, instead of a - i these speakers show a - ə.
Raising does not seem to be conditioned by gutural or emphatic environments, e.g. xibbāz (baker).

Younes (2013: 39) notes that: "La voyelle /a/ se maintient en contexte emphatique dans le schème C1aC2C2āC3: ḥammāl, «porteur». On observe cependant birrād̄ «réfrigérateur». Le maintien s’observe aussi dans le schème C1aC2C3ān: ʕaṭšān ayant soif». Nous avons cependant relevé ʿimyān «aveugle»".
In pre-stressed syllables preeciding short or long vowels, OA *a is usually raised toward i.
Some examples of the pattern CaCCāC display a hesitation in neutral environment, e.g. šabbābih - šibbābih "pan flute"

Behnstedt (1994) notes that the dialect of Soukhne is "conservative" concerning the a-vowel. However he lists a few exceptions, such as sayyāṛa - siyyāṛa (car) and ṭayyāra which becomes ṭiyyāra (airplane).
Fink (2017) notes that the OA vowel a gets dissimilated to ə in nouns with the pattern KaKKāK.
Wittrich (2001) notes that the OA vowel a gets dissimilated to ə in nouns with the pattern KaKKāK.
The phonetic realization of /ə/ is determined by the consonantal environment
Raising to i and u in very few lexemes, no examples provided.

Raising to i and u in some lexemes, no examples provided.
Raising to i and u in some lexemes, e.g. siyyāla (the side pocket of the Galabiyya) or giyyāla (lunch break).

Raising to i and u in some lexemes, e.g. fuwwāda (device to clean the oven) or niššāba (rolling pin).
Raising to i and u in some lexemes, e.g. siyyāla (side pocket of the galabiyya), but gayyāla (lunch break).
Raising to i and u in some lexemes, e.g. siyyāla (side pocket of the galabiyya), but gayyāla (lunch break).

Raising to i and u in some lexemes, e.g. siyyāla (the side pocket of the Galabiyya) or giyyāla (lunch break).
Raising to u when followed by labial.
The raising is optional: in some words there is a raising, in some words there is not, and in others, as malyān/milyān, it is optional.

The raising is optional: in some words there is a raising, in some words there is not, and in others, as malyān/milyān, it is optional.
The raising is optional: in some words there is a raising, in some words there is not, and in others, as malyān/milyān, it is optional.
The raising is optional: in some words there is a raising, in some words there is not, and in others, as malyān/milyān, it is optional.
This raising exists, it is not very current, though.
The raising is optional: in some words there is a raising, in some words there is not, and in others, as malyān/milyān, it is optional.
Raising to i only occurs in very specific cases, e.g. šibbāk (window) and dibbān (flies).

cit.quote: scout who rides ahead of the women and children during migration, looking for pasture
